dc:description:
CACNA1C encodes the alpha-1 subunit (Cav1.2) of the L-type voltage-dependent calcium channel, and colocalizes with RYR in the sarcolemma membrane, indicating a functional role in calcium handling [PMID: 23045342]. CACNA1C expression is observed in cardiac, cerebral, pulmonary, and smooth muscle tissues [PMID: 8392192 & 15454078]. Variants in CACNA1C can disrupt the function of the calcium ion channel and potentially cause arrhythmias. The following summarizes the updated gene curation.

CACNA1C and its association with Brugada syndrome was reported in 2007 by Anzelevitch et al., with two Brugada syndrome patients identified with missense variants (G490R & A39V) in CACNA1C [PMID: 17224476]. However, reviewing recent population databases (GnomAD) revealed the G490R variant was too frequent in healthy populations to be a causative factor for Brugada Syndrome. Burashnikov et al. (2010) identified 9 CACNA1C variants in probands with Brugada Syndrome, Brugada syndrome exhibiting shorter than normal QT intervals, and early repolarization syndrome. Four variants were of interest and absent or rare in gnomAD (p.E1115K, p.A39V, p.E1829_Q1833dup, p.C1837Y), while the remaining five variants were considered common in gnomAD [PMID: 20817017]. Another study in 2013 by Risgaard et al., reported four CACNA1C variants (p.G490R, p.C1837Y, p.R1880Q, V2014I) in 19 probands from the NHLBI GO Exome Sequencing Project. Out of the four, only one was absent or rare in gnomAD (p.C1837Y). The authors noted the cohort lacked provocation testing, some may have been asymptomatic carriers and the mean age was >60 years, which is older than the typical age of diagnosis for Brugada syndrome. Novelli et al. (2022) reported 12 SCN5A-negative Brugada probands with variants in CACNA1C. However five were absent or rare in gnomAD and scored (p.Q428E, p.E850D, p.N1255S, p.G2084E, c.5589-1G>A) [PMID: 34999275]

CACNA1C and its association with Brugada syndrome was evaluated by the Hereditary Cardiovascular GCEP on November 21, 2017. We reviewed this again on February 25, 2025 (SOP v 11). Although new case and cohort studies have been published since 2017 [PMID: 34999275], conflicting evidence remains. Many reported variants in CACNA1C are too common in population databases, and functional studies have shown that both common and rare variants can produce similar effects [PMID: 17224476, 20817017]. The GCEP therefore agreed to maintain the gene–disease classification of CACNA1C and Brugada syndrome as disputed.
curationReasonDescription: Although new case and cohort studies have been published since 2017 [PMID: 34999275], conflicting evidence remains. Many reported variants in CACNA1C are too common in population databases, and functional studies have shown that both common and rare variants can produce similar effects [PMID: 17224476, 20817017]. The GCEP therefore agreed to maintain the gene–disease classification of CACNA1C and Brugada syndrome as disputed.

evidence.dc:description: Observed in pt with BrS and SCN5A -ve. Absent in GnomAD.
Observed in pt with BrS, and reported family history. Absent in GnomAD and authors report it is not present in 404 ethnically matched control either.
Burashnikov et al [20817017] and Risgaard [23414114] report this variant as p.C1837Y, however on GnomAD and ClinVar this was reversed p.Tyr1837Cys.
Observed in pt with BrS and SCN5A -ve, Rare in GnomAD (Allele n=5, Allele freq: 0.000003118), Authors report PolyPhen2 as Damaging.
Observed in pt with SCN5A- BrS, Rare in GnomAD (allele n= 20, allele freq: ),
Too high in GnomAD (4.1) Allele n=111 freq: 6.88e-5. Alternative molecular cause (SCN5A variant also present in proband and family). Doesn't clearly segregate with disease in family.
Authors observed in an individual dx with BrS and SCN5A-, variant is absent in GnomAD,  Polyphen2 and SIFT labelled it as Damaging.
Absent in GnomAD, authors report observed in pt with BrS and highly conserved.
Observed in pt with BrS and SCN5A -ve, Rare in GnomAD (allele n= 1, allele freq: 6.20E-07), authors report Polyphen and SIFT predict damaging.
Observed in pt with BrS and SCN5A -ve. Rare in GnomAD (Allele n=1, Allele freq: 6.20E-07).
Proband's phenotype overlaps more with Timothy syndrome (QT prolongation and autism). Functional studies focused more on QT prolongation rather than the BrS phenotype (ST elevation)

Functional evidence included patch-clamp analysis, drug testing, and computational modeling. Most studies focused on QT prolongation, but one showed a depressed AP plateau in iPSCs, authors hypothesised BrS ECG changes (Figure 3A). 

Patch-clamp analysis showed:
Reduced peak Ca²⁺ current density and impaired Ca²⁺ selectivity.
Increased permeability to monovalent cations. Decreased action potential plateau amplitude, longer action potential duration (APD), and higher frequency of early after depolarizations (EADs) compared to controls.

Drug Testing: Mexiletine and GS-458967 shortened APD specifically in E1115K-iPSC-CMs.
Observed in pt with BrS and SCN5A -ve, rare in GnomAD (allele n=2, Allele freq: 0.000001696).

Shultz et al. reported the cloning and chromosomal localization of an alpha1 subunit cDNA of the L-VDCC from normal human cardiac tissue. Northern Blot analysis showed enriched expression of CACNA1C in human heart, with lesser expression in skeletal muscle, as well as expression in rabbit heart.
evidence.rdfs:label: Schultz et al - Northern blot

evidence.dc:description: Authors characterized voltage-dependent facilitation (VDF) and subcellular localization of Cav1.2 and Cav1.3 channels in mouse SAN cells and determined how these properties of Cav1.3 affect sinoatrial pacemaking in a mathematical model. Using immunofluorescence, authors reported Cav1.3 colocalized with ryanodine receptors in sarcomeric structures while Cav1.2 was largely restricted to the delimiting plasma membrane.
evidence.rdfs:label: Christel et al - IMS analysis

evidence.dc:description: Northern blot analysis of adult and fetal human tissue show expression of CACNA1C exon 8a (alternative exon with more ubiquitious expression) in the heart, brain, intestine, bladder, uterus, prostate (Figure 3). They also show in situ hybridization of mouse tissue and show high expression in several brain regions in the heart (ventricles), eye, developing digits, and tooth papilla.
evidence.rdfs:label: Splawski et al - Nothern blot
